values.alignmentText: For Trey's .NET career, North Korea's command economy assigns coders to state bureaus, leaving no private market or freedom to work remotely, so he'd have no viable job path.
Coal-fired heating, dust storms, and aging industry keep PM2.5 well above safe thresholds, leaving the boys' lungs exposed to the kind of pollution we try to avoid.
Although the regime is officially atheist, loyalty tests and punishment for dissent turn secularism into coercion, so our preference for freely chosen beliefs would be impossible.
A hereditary totalitarian state with no civil liberties directly violates our family's insistence on resilient democracies.
Sanctions and ration cards dominate commerce, and foreigners cannot rely on cards or modern payments, meaning daily transactions would be nearly impossible for us.
While the peninsula has coastline, militarization and lack of amenities mean our family would rarely reach a safe, pleasant beach.
State surveillance and bans on unsanctioned gatherings erase the hobby scenes Trey and the kids love, leaving that community nonexistent.
Work units run nurseries with poor resources and heavy indoctrination, so even with nominal coverage we couldn't trust the care for the boys.
Crumbling infrastructure, blackouts, and constant surveillance make cities stressful for our boys instead of nurturing.
Citizen families get assigned childcare, but quality and autonomy are so poor that parents trade safety and enrichment for state monitoring.
Foreigners almost never live here long-term and would receive no childcare guarantees, leaving us without any support network.
Recreational activities are dictated by propaganda, leaving no overlap with our geeky, creative interests.
Trust is enforced through informants, creating fearful, state-directed communities that are the opposite of the open networks we seek.
Minor rule breaches can land families in labor camps, so the risk of severe punishment would hang over every routine decision.
Official prices seem low, but scarcity and bribes devour income, making everyday affordability wildly unstable.
The regime does not recognize dual citizenship, so our family would lose U.S. protection with no recourse.
Chronic sanctions, famine risk, and negligible growth leave the economy stagnant and offer no prospects for entrepreneurs like us.
A rigid command economy eliminates private enterprise, blocking any path to prosperity or independent work.
Schools emphasize ideology over learning, and materials are outdated, so our kids would miss the critical thinking and resources they need.
No private employers can sponsor foreigners, shutting down any legitimate way to live and work here.
Deforestation, pollution, and limited conservation leave few healthy outdoor spaces for family time.
Income rules are arbitrary and foreigners' pay is seized or rationed, so we could not rely on transparent taxation or even access to earnings.
Autumn swings between chilly winds and mild afternoons (roughly 5–20°C/41–68°F), forcing constant wardrobe changes that complicate the boys' routines.
State dictates roles and punishes nonconformity, the opposite of the supportive family culture we need.
Collective punishment can target entire families for one person's misstep, so safety for loved ones is never assured.
While pronatalist benefits exist, they come with surveillance and ideological requirements, turning support into coercion.
A 'normal' family is defined rigidly as hetero and obedient, leaving no room for our polyamory-positive values.
Foreign families seldom gain residency and face constant oversight, so policies effectively exclude outsiders like us.
Women must follow state-issued styles and badges, smothering Sarah's personal expression.
Men are expected to wear approved haircuts and uniforms, erasing Trey's ability to present himself authentically.
Femininity is tied to obedience and motherhood under surveillance, far from Sarah's need for autonomy.
No independent studios exist, so Trey cannot build or join a game dev community.
Gender variance is criminalized and policed, making safety and acceptance impossible for gender-diverse friends or family.
Women work and serve in the military but lack autonomy; forced loyalty keeps rights shallow and unreliable.
Roles are centrally assigned, and deviation is punished, leaving no flexibility for our household.
Foreigners live under escorts, restricted internet, and exit controls, so daily life would be untenable.
The peninsula faces worsening droughts, floods, and crop failures, so climate change is already disrupting basic safety nets.
Hospitals lack medicine and power, so families rely on informal markets and still struggle to find reliable care.
Foreigners must use under-equipped clinics under surveillance, leaving us without safe medical support.
University slots depend on loyalty and songbun status, so merit and academic quality are routinely compromised.
Foreign students rarely enroll and face tight controls, making real higher education access practically impossible.
Apartments are allocated by the state, often without heat or maintenance, so housing would be unreliable and uncomfortable.
Taxes and 'patriotic donations' are arbitrary with no digital tools, turning compliance into a punitive guessing game.
Schooling is universal but under-resourced and indoctrinating, so our kids would receive little actual education.
Foreign kids cannot attend regular schools and only receive monitored tutoring, which keeps them isolated and under watch.
Queer identities are denied by the state, making life unsafe for our polyamory-positive, LGBTQ+-affirming household.
English is tightly controlled and interpreters are state-provided, so we would lack autonomy in even basic communication.
The population must publicly embrace Juche-Marxist rhetoric regardless of private belief, so coerced ideology shapes every interaction.
Masculinity equates to military obedience, which conflicts with Trey's creative identity and emotional style.
Unofficial gatherings risk arrest, leaving no safe space for the open-source or parenting meetups we rely on.
Wages are symbolic and distributed through rationing, so pay protections mean nothing in practice.
Power outages, limited broadband, and outdated transport keep infrastructure failing when we'd need stability for remote work and schooling.
The mountains and coasts are scenic, yet travel permits and limited maintenance restrict access, so the landscapes are hard to enjoy.
Floods and typhoons regularly overwhelm infrastructure, turning disasters into routine disruptions.
Even hikes require escorts and permits, so our outdoorsy family would struggle to reach nature on our own terms.
Entertainment is propaganda-focused, leaving no authentic nightlife for adults to unwind.
Curfews and surveillance suppress evening social life entirely, so there is no casual night culture to join.
There are no independent dev meetups or studios to learn from, so Trey would lose vital peer networks.
Only state propaganda studios exist, providing no career or mentorship for Trey.
Private startups are illegal, so launching an indie studio would be impossible.
Daily routines are rigid and punctuated by mandatory meetings, so even quiet streets feel stressful for Sarah.
Parents must enforce ideology and collective rituals, which clashes with the values we want to model for the boys.
Naturalization is effectively impossible for foreigners, keeping the door closed to permanent status.
Every service requires bribes or loyalty, so corruption would dominate day-to-day life.
A one-party dictatorship with dynastic leadership leaves no room for the democratic norms we require.
Polyamorous relationships are unthinkable and dangerous, contradicting our family's openness.
State nurseries provide coverage but prioritize indoctrination over enrichment, so we'd worry about what the boys are taught.
Private schools are banned, leaving no alternative to ideological classrooms.
Progressive civil society does not exist; politics revolves around loyalty, so our values would have no outlet.
Every broadcast, poster, and classroom lecture glorifies the Kim family and war readiness, crushing the empathetic, humanity-first narratives we value.
State networks monopolize information, from neighborhood speakers to party newspapers, leaving zero room for independent or compassionate perspectives.
Pyongyang's metro and buses reach few areas, and foreigners are restricted, leaving us with minimal usable transit.
Religion is suppressed yet replaced by quasi-spiritual loyalty to the Kim family, so ideology still intrudes on civic life.
Internet access is locked behind state intranets, making remote work impossible for Trey or Sarah.
Only tightly controlled short stays are allowed, so long-term residency plans collapse immediately.
Elders rely on rationing and family support with little healthcare, keeping retirement insecure.
Foreign retirees are not permitted, leaving us no path to age in place here.
There is no Ruby ecosystem or open internet, so Sarah would have no way to practice her craft.
Street crime is low, but arbitrary detention keeps us uneasy because state threats replace criminal risk.
We would have no school choice beyond ideological classrooms, eliminating any alternative for the boys.
Cold currents keep water chilly outside brief summer weeks, so family beach trips would rarely be comfortable.
Harsh winters, muggy monsoons, and dusty springs mean constant adaptation that would wear us down.
Sex education is censored and premarital sex punished, creating a repressive environment for healthy conversations.
Policy is designed to control citizens rather than expand rights, so reforms never aim to improve personal freedom.
Dust storms and swings between chilly mornings and mild afternoons (5–17°C/41–63°F) demand constant adjustments our family would struggle with.
The regime appears stable, but sanctions and famine risk create persistent volatility we couldn't plan around.
Juche doctrine requires absolute devotion, contradicting our pluralistic values.
Only black markets operate quietly; formal capitalism is banned, so we'd rely on risky informal trade for basics.
Humid monsoon highs near 30°C/86°F with little relief, plus power shortages, make summers oppressive for the whole household.
Visa processes are opaque, expensive, and often denied, so we'd burn time and money for paperwork that rarely succeeds.
Citizens must feign trust to avoid punishment, so genuine trust and accountability are nonexistent.
Petty bribes and elite graft permeate every service, meaning corruption shapes every transaction.
Programmers earn ration coupons, not market wages, leaving tech workers without sustainable income.
Weekends require propaganda events and community labor, leaving no family downtime.
Mandatory overtime and political meetings erase evenings, crushing family time.
Leave is nominal and controlled by work units, so vacations exist only on paper.
Even approved leave comes with travel bans and reporting, making true rest impossible.
State media vilifies neighbors, encouraging hostility that conflicts with our desire for regional openness.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Neighbors view the regime with suspicion and sanction it, so regional relationships stay strained.
Propaganda elevates self-reliance myths and discourages humility, fostering an insular national self-image.
Only brief, escorted visits are possible, leaving no workable immigration pathway.
Americans are rarely admitted and heavily surveilled, so we'd be treated as suspects, not neighbors.
The media environment offers research value for understanding propaganda, but nearly every practical aspect of life fails our family's priorities, so we cap intrigue at a cautious 2.
Winters plunge to -13°C/8°F with biting winds and limited heating, making the cold harsh beyond our comfort.
Long hours plus mandatory sessions keep workweeks exhausting with no flexibility.
State demands override family autonomy, leaving Sarah without the balance she needs.
Forced labor, no unions, and collective punishment strip workers of any real protections.
